document.docAuthor: Ruess, Liliane & Sandbach, Peter & Cudlín, Pavel & Dighton, John & Crossley, Alan
document.docTitle: Acid deposition in a spruce forest soil: effects on nematodes, mycorrhizas and fungal biomass

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Acid deposition in a spruce forest soil: effects on nematodes, mycorrhizas and fungal biomass

heading.emphasis: Acid deposition in a spruce forest soil: effects on nematodes, mycor ­ rhizas and fungal biomass

paragraph.emphasis: Liliane Ruess 1 , Peter Sandbach 1, Pavel Cudlín 2, John Dighton 1, 3 and Alan Crossley 4

subSection.paragraph: 1 Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Merlewood Research Station, Grange-over-Sands, Cumbria LA 11 6JU, UK
2 Institute of Landscape Ecology, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, Na sádkách 7, 37005 Ceské Budejovice, Czech Republic
3 Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences, Division of Pinelands Research, Department of Biology, Rutgers University, Camden, New Jersey 08102, USA
4 Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Bush Estate, Penicuik, Midlothian EH26 0QB, UK

Summary. The belowground biota (nematodes, fungal biomass, roots and mycorrhizal development) of a mature Sitka spruce stand under the influence of acid precipitation (equimolar sulphuric acid and ammonium nitrate) was investigated. Sampling took place after 3 years of treatment and 5 months after the end of treatment. Acidification led to a decrease of the soil pH from 5.0 to 4.0 in the upper 2 cm of soil. The active fungal biomass, measured as the ergosterol content of the soil, increased. After the end of the acid treatment pH differences decreased between plots. The active fungal biomass was lower, but the amount of total fungal hyphae was higher at the acid treated plots. Additionally, precipitation of acid mist led to an acceleration of fine root and mycorrhizal development and their senescence.

A total of 79 nematode species were found in the plots. Acidification caused a distinct decrease in species number, especially among K -strategists like omnivores and predators. The population density was not altered, but the dominance and abundance structure of the community changed.
Acrobeloides nanus
,
Metateratocephalus crassidens
and
Aphelenchoides spp.
showed a higher frequency at the acidified plots. Others, like
Cervidellus serratus ,
Filenchus spp.
or
Aporcelaimellus obtusicaudatus,
decreased. Among the trophic groups, the occurrence of omnivore and predatory nematodes was affected negatively by acidification. The proportion of fungal feeding nematodes increased under acid precipitation, but the effect did not last after the end of the treatment. This corresponds to the amount of the active fungal biomass measured in the soil, indicating that the composition of the nematode fauna is changing with the presence or absence of their food source.
Key words: Spruce forest, acidification, nematodes, root density, fungal biomass, mycorrhiza

footnote.paragraph: Correspondence to: Liliane Ruess, Institut fur Biologie II — RWTH Aachen — KopernikusstraBe 16, 5100 Aachen, Germany

subSection.paragraph: The trees are a single clone, 22 yr old, taken as cuttings from a parent tree in 1972. The cuttings were initially propagated in pots and were transferred to the field site in 1984 as a 12 x 12 block with 2.5 m spacing. For the acid treatment spray chambers were designed to enclose blocks of 4 trees. Each chamber comprised a framework of galvanised steel poles supporting fixed panels of glass-reinforced plastic sheeting and a set of polythene roller blinds. The latter were drawn down to make the chamber side walls, only for the duration of the acid mist application (approx. 20 min). The control trees were unchambered and didn’t receive any treatment. In 1992 a control experiment was set up to investigate chamber effects. The result of this test showed that the growth of sprayed chamber controls was identical to that of unsprayed, unchambered control trees (Crossley, pers. com.). Growth, frost hardiness and aboveground damage of the trees were recorded by the ITE Bush (for details see Crossley et al. 1992 , 1995 ). The experiment was carried out with 2 treatments (control, acid mist), and 3 replicate plots per treatment. The acid treatment at pH 2.5 was an equimolar mixture of H2 SO4 and NH4NO3 (1.6 mol m-3 SO4, NO 3, NH4 and 3.2 mol m-3 H +). Treatments began in July 1990 and stopped in November 1993. During the growth season of the trees (usually May to November) acid mist was applied 50 times each at 2 mm equivalent deposition (501 per chamber). Total inputs of S, N, and H + were 54.6, 47.8, and 3.4 kg ha- 1, respectively. This was apparently double the annual inputs in total precipitation of upland forest areas in southern Scotland of 25 —35 kg ha- 1 S and N, and 0.5 — 0.7 kg ha1 H + ( Crossley et al. 1992 ).

Nine replicate soil samples were taken with a soil corer (2.5 cm diameter) from each treatment plot and divided into 0 — 2, 2 — 4, and 4 — 6 cm depths. They were stored (max. 30 h) at 4 °C until extraction. Samples were taken twice, in October 1993 and April 1994. Nematodes were extracted from soil using a modified Baermann method (see Ruess 1995a ). The soil was placed on a porous filter (cotton discs for manual milk filtration, 16 cm diameter) supported by a wire screen at the top of a funnel (9 cm diameter). The funnel was connected to a small glass vial (25 ml) and the whole system was filled with tap water. Nematodes were extracted for 24 h at room temperature (13 — 15 °C). Then a heating regime was started using electric bulbs placed over the extraction funnels. Temperature reached 42 °C after 4 h and samples were kept there for a total of 6 h. Nematodes were preserved in 4% formaldehyde solution (60 °C). The number of nematodes extracted from each sample was counted and 10% of the nematodes (but not less than 100) were identified. Altogether 42800 nematodes were counted and 10500 of them were determined to genus or species. The classification of trophic groups is according to Yeates et al. (1993 a) .

caption.paragraph: Table 1. Soil pH (in H2O) and water content (as % of DW soil) in control and acid treated plots at different soil depths in October 1993 and April 1994. Data are means of 3 replicate samples. * significant different to the control with P <0.10

subSection.paragraph: One gram soil samples (9 replicates per treatment), to be analysed for ergosterol content, were suspended in 30 ml methanol and transferred to 250 ml round bottom flasks and refluxed for 2 h. Afterwards they were filtered to remove soil particles and saponified with 5 ml of KOH (3.2%) in ethanol by refluxing for 30 min. When cooled, 10 ml H2O were added and the solutions were extracted 3 times with pentane (10, 5 and 5 ml). The pentane extracts were evaporated to dryness overnight (30 °C). The residues were redissolved in 1 ml methanol prior to quantification using a reverse-phase HPLC system at a wavelength of 282 nm.

Roots were separated from the sand by washing under a tap, over a sieve with mesh aperture 0.5 mm. Roots (cut into 50 mm length) and root fragments were randomly placed on a metal tray marked with grid lines. According to the generator of random numbers 5 grid squares were selected in different patterns. These representative root subsamples were immediately fixed in glutaraldehyde and divided into 2 categories, coarse roots (> 1 mm diameter) and fine roots (<1 mm diameter). The length of the fine roots was determined using the grid line intersect method of Giovannetti & Mosse (1980) .

For statistical analysis a standard nonparametric and robust method, the Mann-Whitney U test, was used. With this test a pairwise ranking of treatments was made for the data obtained (e.g. fungal biomass, root length, nematode population density). The test of each pair does not depend on the other treatments in the study. This robust method was chosen, because with the lack of a random block design for sampling, a spatial pseudo replication of data occurred.

Additionally, linear regression analysis was carried out to investigate correlation between nematode community structure (e.g. trophic groups) and fungal biomass. Samples for root development were not taken into consideration, because they were not taken simultaneously with the other samples.

Soil pH and water content of the investigated plots are given in Table 1 . After treatment with acid mist soil pH was clearly reduced. These effects were significant for all soil depths in October 1993. Changes were more obvious in the upper soil layer (0 — 2 cm), where the soil pH was 5.0 at the control and 4.0 at the acidified plots. Acid treatment stopped in November 1993, and differences in the pH decreased between plots. In April 1994 in 0 — 2 cm soil depth the pH was 4.9 at the control and 4.5 at the acidified plots. In deeper soil layers pH values were almost equal. Application of acid mist increased the soil water content in October 1993. No higher soil moisture was found in April 1994, after the end of the treatment.

Total mycelial mass (hyphal length) and active fungal hyphae (ergosterol) were used to assess the fungal biomass in the soil (Fig. 1). Total and viable biomass showed differing vertical distribution in the soil. The ergosterol content decreased strongly with depth. More than 90 % of the ergosterol was concentrated in 0 — 2 cm soil layer, but only 59 to 66 % of the total fungal mycelia were found here as determined by hyphal length counts.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Total fungal hyphal length (m/g DW + s.d.) in April 1994 (a) and er ­ gosterol content (gg/g DW + s.d.) in April 1994 (b) and October 1993 (c) in control and acid treated plots at diffe ­ rent soil depths. Data are means of 9 replicates. * significant different to the control plots with P <0.05

Table 2. Phases (1 to 5) of root tip development (no tips/cm ± s.d.) and vitality degrees (for details see Materials and Methods) in root ingrowth cores of control and acid treated plots. Root ingrowth cores (12 replicates) were harvested in November 1993 after 7 months

subSection.paragraph:
A total of 79 different species were found at the plots, of which 18 could only be determined to genus ( Table 3 ). Usually the occurrence of these 18 taxa was rare, making it difficult to assign them to described species. The classification into trophic groups was made according to Yeates et al. (1993 a) . Overall numbers of species were distributed differently. The bacterial feeders were the most common group with 33 species, followed by plant feeders with 22 species. The latter group includes mainly ectoparasites or epidermal cell and root hair feeders, but some migratory endoparasites or semiendoparasites were also observed. Other feeding types found were 9 fungal hyphae feeding species, 7 omnivores and 7 predators. Only one species belonged to the group of unicellular eucaryote feeders, which feed on diatoms or algae, as well as ingesting fungal spores or yeast cells. Eudominant (> 10%) on at least one sampling date and soil depth were the bacterial feeders
Acrobeloides nanus
,
Alaimus primitivus
and
Metateratocephalus crassidens,
the fungal feeder
Aphelenchoides macronucleatus,
and the ectoparasite
Cephalenchus megacephalus.

caption.paragraph: Table 3. Nematode species observed in control and acid treated plots (both sampling dates). Trophic groups according to Yeates et al. (1993 a) . + + + + + = eudominant (> 10%), + + + + = dominant (5 —10%), + + + = subdominant (2 — 5%), + + = resedent (1 — 2%), + = subresedent (<1 %) on at least one sampling date and soil depth; — occurrence of males

td.taxonomicName: Drilocephalobus cf. goodeyi Ali, Suryawanshi & Chisty, 1973

tr.td:
♂ ♂
Aphelenchoides macronucleatus Baranovskaya
,
Ditylenchus intermedius (De Man, 1880)
1963

subSection.paragraph:
Acidification caused a decrease in the total number of species from 77 at the control plots to 62 at the acid mist plots ( Table 3 ). These effects were most evident among the omnivores and predators, where numbers were reduced to about half. The dominance structure of the different species varied between treatments. The occurrence of many bacterial feeding species was reduced after acid mist precipitation. Others, like
M. crassidens
, were more dominant. In particular some frequent fungal and plant feeders showed different distribution patterns. The fungal feeding species
Deladenus sp.
and
Diphtherophora vanoyei
made up to 5 % of the population at the control plots, but were not detected at the acid mist plots, where
Tylolaimophorus typicus
was more common. Among the plant feeders the genus
Filenchus
was negatively affected by acid treatment, but
Paratylenchus
and
Cephalenchus
seemed to gain importance. Almost all omnivore and predatory species were less dominant after acidification. In Table 4 species numbers in the different soil layers of the plots are given. Between 39 and 54 nematodes species were observed. Species numbers were higher at the control plots at all sampling dates and depths.

caption.paragraph: Table 4. Number of nematode species observed in control and acid treated plots at different soil depths. Overall numbers out of 9 replicate samples are presented. Samples taken in October 1993 and April 1994

Table 5. Population density (Ind/g DW ± s.d.) of nematodes and proportion (% ± s.d.) of juveniles and males in control and acid treated plots at different soil depths. Samples (9 replicates) were taken in October 1993 and April 1994
Table 6. Abundance (Ind/g DW ± s.d.) of frequent nematode taxa in control and acid treated plots at different soil depths. Samples (9 replicates) were taken in October 1993 and April 1994

subSection.paragraph:
Acidification also influenced the abundance of species ( Table 6 ). Some taxa, like
A.
nanus,
M. crassidens
or
Aphelenchoides spp.
were more frequent at the acid mist plots, especially in the upper soil layer. After the end of the acid treatment the abundance of
M . crassidens
increased extremely to reach 87.6 Ind/g DW in 0 — 2 cm soil depth of the acid mist plots, compared to the control with 7.5 Ind/g DW. Other species were negatively affected by acid precipitation. The occurrence of
Cervidellus serratus
was lower at both sampling dates, while
Filenchus spp.
and
Aporcelaimellus obtusicaudatus
seemed to recover slowly in April 1994.

The proportions of omnivores, predators and unicellular eucaryote feeders were reduced after acidification at all sampling dates and depths. This decrease was significant (P <0.05) for the omnivore nematodes in 0 — 2 and 4 — 6 cm soil depth in October 1993 and in 0 — 2 cm soil depth in April 1994.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Proportion (%) of trophic groups of nematodes in control and acid treated plots at different soil depths in October 1993 and in April 1994. Data are means of 9 replicates

subSection.paragraph:
Only a few studies on the distribution of free-living nematodes in British soils are available. Most of them describe populations in grasslands or moorlands ( Banage 1962 , 1966 ; Hodda & Wanless 1994 ; Yeates 1970 ; Yuen 1966 ). In the present study a Sitka spruce stand was investigated. Altogether 79 species were identified and some of them were new records for Britain. The trees are growing on formerly agricultural land and the ground was partly covered by grasses. Both conditions appear to influence the composition of the nematode fauna. Compared to other European coniferous forests, some typical genera, such as
Teratocephalus
or
Wilsonema
, were rare or missing and the species number and frequency of plant parasites was high (see Bassus 1962 ; de Goede & Bongers 1994 ; Háněl 1993 ; Ruess 1995 b ). Among plant parasites Boag (1974) found 5 dominant genera under Sitka spruce in Scotland. Two of them,
Rotylenchus
and
Paratylenchus ,
were also very common at the spruce stand investigated. The main difference to his observations was the low occurrence of
Tylencholaimus
and
Helicotylenchus
, which were scarce in Glencorse soils. All predatory species were also less frequent.

Acidification caused a distinct decrease in species number, especially among K-strategists such as predators or omnivores. In contrast, population density was not altered. Similar results were reported by Dmowska (1993) and Ruess et al. (1993) in soil microcosm or field experiments. Other authors found a decrease in numbers of nematodes after acidification ( Hyvönen & Persson 1990 ; Timans 1986 ). The soils in both treatments were only slightly acid, and the decrease of some sensitive species is likely to be compensated by an increase of others, leading to changes in the dominance structure as observed in this experiment.

Most nematodes in forest soils feed on bacteria or fungi ( Sohlenius 1980 ), and variations in pH affect their food source, the soil microorganisms. Griffiths et al. (1994) reported that changes in nematode community structure are related to changes in the food availability and in consequence to microbial changes in the soil. Bacterial feeders were the most abundant group in the present plots. Their proportion of the nematode community was not altered by acidification, suggesting adequate bacterial food supply in the soil. This corresponds with results of Bååth et al. (1992) and Shafer (1992) , who found relatively constant bacterial numbers but altered bacterial assemblages after acidification. As discussed above, the active fungal biomass was higher in the upper soil layer after acidification, but decreased after the end of the treatment. The same trend was shown by the fungal feeding nematodes. This indicates that the species composition of nematodes changes with the presence or absence of active fungal hyphae. In microcosm experiments Bååth et al. (1978) found changing fungal production in soil led to similar observations.

Most affected by acid treatment were omnivores and predators. Generally, these nematodes are K-strategists with low reproduction rate and long life-cycles ( Bongers 1990 ). Ferris & Ferris (1974) and Yeates (1981) report that especially the dorylaimid fauna is negatively affected by highly disturbed forest sites. In the present experiment their populations did not recover 5 months after the end of the acidification. They seem to be very sensitive to environmental disturbance and may be of good use as bioindicators in soil ecosystems.

This work was funded by a NATO fellowship from the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD Bonn) and by a Human Capital and Mobility grant from the CEC. We would like to thank Jan Poskitt and Dr. Lucy Sheppard for technical assistance and practical advice.
